questions.text: Which of the following is a secondary air pollutant, not a primary one?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Ozone (O3) is a secondary pollutant, not a primary one.

Classification of Air Pollutants:

  • Primary Air Pollutants:
    • Emitted directly into the atmosphere:
      • Mobile sources: e.g., vehicle exhaust pipes.
      • Stationary sources: e.g., factory chimneys.
    • Examples include:
      • Carbon monoxide (CO) (Option A)
      • Sulfur dioxide (SO2) (Option B)
      • Oxides of nitrogen (Option D)
      • Volatile organic compounds
      • Primary particles (carbonaceous and non-carbonaceous)
  • Secondary Air Pollutants:
    • Formed by chemical reactions in the atmosphere involving natural components (e.g., water, oxygen).
    • Examples include:
      • Ozone (O3) (Option C)
      • Particulate matter (PM)
      • Oxides of nitrogen (can also be formed secondarily)

Reference:

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC8099844/

questions.text: All of the following are indicators of air pollution except:
questions.solution:
Explanation of Answer:

BOD is an indicator of water pollution, not air pollution.

Monitoring of Air Pollution:

  1. Sulphur Dioxide (SO2): (Option A)
    • Major contaminant in urban and industrial areas.
    • Its concentration is routinely estimated in air pollution surveys.
  2. Smoke / Soiling Index: (Option B)
    • A specific volume of air is passed through a white filter paper.
    • The stain on the paper is measured using a photoelectric meter.
    • Smoke concentration is expressed in micrograms per cubic metre (μg/m³).
    • Reported as an average level over a specific period.
  3. Grit and Dust Measurement:
    • Collected using deposit gauges.
    • Includes grit, dust, and other solid particles.
    • Analysed every month.
  4. Coefficient of Haze:
    • Assesses the amount of smoke or aerosol in the air.
  5. Air Pollution Index (API): (Option C)
    • An arbitrary index combining multiple pollutants to reflect severity.
    • A value above 50 is considered alarming.

questions.text: McArdle's maximum allowable sweat rate is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

McArdle identified 45 litres of sweat in 4 hours as the maximum allowable sweat rate for healthy, acclimatised young men under repeated heat exposure.

McArdle's Maximum Allowable Sweat Rate (PSR):

  • McArdle and associates studied sweat rates in heat exposure.
  • Maximum Allowable Sweat Rate:5 litres of sweat in 4 hours is the maximum allowable rate.
  • Population Studied: Acclimatised, healthy young men under repeated heat exposure.
  • Physiological Basis: This sweat rate is considered compatible with a normal physiological reaction.
  • PSR Chart: They developed a chart to predict the Four-Hour Sweat Rate (PSR).
  • Chart Inputs: The PSR can be obtained using:
    • Dry bulb temperature
    • Wet bulb temperature
    • Mean radiant temperature
    • Air velocity
    • Metabolic (work) intensity
  • Comfort Zone: A PSR value of 3 is the upper limit of the comfort zone.

questions.text: The temperature range considered "Comfortable" where a person can maintain thermal balance without sweating is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

25-27°C is regarded as the comfortable temperature zone in which thermal balance is maintained without sweating.

Comfort Zones:

  • Comfort zones refer to the range of Effective Temperature Scale (ETS) values where most adults feel thermally comfortable.
  • Influencing Factors:
    • Physical factors
    • Physiological factors
    • Psychological factors (often hard to quantify)
  • Thermal Comfort (Environmental Focus): Defined as the condition in which a person maintains normal body temperature without sweating, due to a balance between heat production and heat loss.
  • Comfort Zones Evaluated in India (Based on Corrected Effective Temperature):

questions.text: What is the recommended minimum daylight factor in a living room for adequate natural illumination?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The recommended daylight factor in living rooms is at least 8% to ensure sufficient indoor illumination.

Measurement of Daylight:

  • Daylight Factor (D.F.): A more reliable measure is the Daylight Factor, which expresses the ratio of indoor to outdoor illumination.
  • Definition of D.F.:
  • Standard Outdoor Reference: Outdoor illumination is taken as 500 foot candles, excluding direct sunlight.
  • Recommended Values:
    • Living rooms: Minimum 8% daylight factor
    • Kitchens: Minimum 10% daylight factor

questions.text: All of the following are types of mechanical ventilation except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cross ventilation is a natural, not mechanical, ventilation method using wind flow through openings.

Types of Mechanical Ventilation:

  1. Exhaust Ventilation: (Option A)
    • Air is removed by exhaust fans, creating a vacuum that draws in fresh air.
    • Common in large halls/auditoria.
    • Fans placed high on external walls to remove hot air.
    • Used in industries to remove dust/fumes at source.
  2. Plenum Ventilation: (Option B)
    • Fresh air is blown in using centrifugal fans, creating positive pressure.
    • Pushes out stale air.
    • Used in air-conditioned buildings/factories via ducts.
    • Limited utility.
  3. Balanced Ventilation: (Option C)
    • Combines exhaust and plenum systems.
    • Fans work in balance; no natural ventilation used.
    • Offers controlled airflow.
  4. Air Conditioning:
    • Controls temperature, humidity, air movement, dust, bacteria, odours, gases.
    • Used in hospitals, industries, homes.
    • Filters and conditions air before recirculation.
    • Central systems preferred in large buildings for efficiency.

questions.text: The cooling power of air is best measured by:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Kata thermometer measures the cooling power of air.

Kata Thermometer:

  • Structure:
    • Alcohol thermometer with a glass bulb (4 cm long, 1.8 cm diameter).
    • Readings marked from 100°F to 95°F on the stem.
    • Two types:
      • Wet Kata: Bulb wrapped in wet muslin.
      • Dry Kata: Bulb left dry.
  • Purpose:
    • Originally used to measure cooling power of air.
    • Now mainly used as an anemometer for low air velocity
  • Indicators of Thermal Comfort:
    • Dry Kata reading ≥ 6
    • Wet Kata reading ≥ 20

Explanation of other options:

Hygrometer (Option B): Measures humidity, not the cooling power of air.

Anemometer (Option C): Measures wind speed or air velocity, not cooling power.

Sling psychrometer (Option D): Measures relative humidity using wet and dry bulb temperatures, not directly the cooling power of air.

questions.text: Which of the following instruments is not used for the measurement of humidity?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Globe thermometer is used to measure mean radiant temperature, not humidity.

Measurement of Humidity:

  1. Dry and Wet Bulb Hygrometer: (Option A)
    • Most commonly used instrument for measuring humidity.
    • Components:
      • Two similar thermometers:
        • Dry Bulb Thermometer (DBT): Measures air temperature.
        • Wet Bulb Thermometer (WBT): Bulb covered with gauze/wick, kept moist.
    • Working Principle:
      • WBT is usually lower than DBT due to evaporation.
      • If both readings are equal, it indicates 100% relative humidity (RH) (rare in real life).
  2. Sling (Whirling) Psychrometer: (Option C)
    • Components:
      • Two mercury thermometers (wet and dry) mounted side by side on a wooden frame with a handle.
    • Working Principle:
      • Instrument is rotated to expose bulbs to air at a constant velocity.
  3. Assmann Psychrometer: (Option D)
    • Portable instrument for accurate measurement of wet and dry bulb temperatures.
    • Advantage:
      • Can be used in strong sunlight without distortion of readings.

Decline in grain production due to soil moisture loss

questions.text: Which of the following is not a predicted consequence of global warming?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Rise in sea level by 2 meters by 2050 is incorrect because the predicted rise is only 0.1 to 0.3 metres by 2050.

Global Warming:

  • Caused by greenhouse gas emissions, mainly CO2 from fossil fuel combustion.
  • Predicted effects:
    • ~3°C rise in global temperature by 2030.
    • 1-0.3 m sea level rise by 2050. (Option B)
    • More cyclones, heatwaves, and droughts. (Option A)
  • May exceed species' adaptive capacity, affecting ecosystems, water, agriculture, health, and urban planning.
  • Small changes can trigger large impacts (catastrophe theory).
  • Rainfall and wind patterns may shift: some areas become wetter, others drier.
  • Hotter summers, lower soil moisture, and a decline in grain yield. (Option D)
  • Change in insect vector distribution. (Option C)
  • Urban heat island effect leads to more intense heatwaves.

choices.text: Ministry of Health and Family Welfare

questions.text: Which agency is responsible for initiating the National Air Quality Monitoring Programme (NAMP) in India?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Air Pollution Monitoring in India:

  • The National Air Quality Monitoring Programme (NAMP) was initiated by the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) in 1990.
  • Covers 10 major Indian cities: Ahmedabad, Mumbai, Kolkata, Delhi, Hyderabad, Jaipur, Kanpur, Kochi, Chennai, Nagpur.

Explanation of other options:

Central Research Institute (Option A) focuses on vaccine production and public health research; it is not involved in air quality monitoring.

Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (Option B) deals with public health and healthcare services, but does not directly monitor environmental pollution like air quality.

National Environmental Engineering Research Institute (Option C) provides technical research and consultancy, but it is not the official monitoring body for air pollution in India.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indoor air pollutant?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Ozone is mainly an outdoor air pollutant formed by the reaction of sunlight with nitrogen oxides and volatile organic compounds, and is not commonly generated by indoor sources.

questions.text: On the day following Diwali, the Central Pollution Control Board recorded an Air Quality Index (AQI) of 470 in Delhi due to high levels of pollutants such as carbon monoxide, carbon dioxide, and sulphur dioxide. According to CPCB classification, which category does this AQI level fall under?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The AQI value of 470 falls within the "Severe" category (AQI range 401-500) as per the CPCB Air Quality Index classification.

Reference:

https://airquality.cpcb.gov.in/AQI_India/

choices.text: Auditory fatigue commonly occurs around 60 dB and affects low-frequency sounds.
Temporary hearing loss usually recovers within a few days and occurs in the 100-200 Hz range.
Occupational hearing loss results from repeated exposure to noise around 100 dB.
Exposure to 90 dB noise can rupture the tympanic membrane.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding auditory effects of noise pollution is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Occupational hearing loss is caused by repeated or continuous exposure to noise around 100 dB, leading to permanent inner ear damage.

Auditory Effects of Noise Pollution:

  1. Auditory Fatigue:
    • Begins around 90 dB, most prominent at 4000 Hz. (Option A)
    • May cause whistling or buzzing in the ears.
    • Usually reversible after rest from noise exposure.
  2. Deafness (Hearing Loss):
    • Most serious auditory effect of noise pollution.
    • Victim is often unaware in the early stages.
    • Can be:
      • Temporary: (Option B)
        • Due to specific noise exposure.
        • Usually recovers within 24 hours.
        • Most common in the 4000-6000 Hz range.
      • Permanent:
        • Caused by continuous/repeated exposure to noise around 100 dB.
        • Damage ranges from minor hair cell changes to destruction of the Corti.
        • If work-related, called occupational hearing loss. (Option C)
      • Sudden Permanent Loss:
        • Exposure above 160 dB may rupture the tympanic membrane. (Option D)
        • Leads to irreversible deafness.
